A space-shuttle is not a necessary condition for building a space station. One can do this easily unmanned and much more efficiently by simple rockets - the way that Russians do it. The empty Space-shuttle itself weighs 70 tons or so, which means a lot of wasted rocket energy for an empty box. Compare this with the weight of a module, usually about 15 tons, transported by the shuttle...

BEAM is the future. If we want to build a Moon base or go to MARS we need a place to put our astronauts and that place is BEAM. How it works is nylon straps hold the module down for launch in the trunk of Dragon or inside of a Delta IV rocket once the module reaches space it is extracted, mated to the station, and attached to a tire pump and inflated. Those UFOs you see during the inflation are the straps as BEAM is inflated the pressure removes the adhesive on the back of Velcro tabs and the straps are wadded up in Mylar and jettisoned as the module inflates. Once BEAM reaches it's full size it is the size of a small car or a closet. The larger modules will be the size of a bus and bigger. Biggalo is already making the next modules and these will go to the Moon.

That's just bullshit. Let's compare payload to Leo.
Delta 4 Heavy: 27500 kg (I've also seen 22500kg. Don't know which is right)
Falcon 9: 22800kg (if expended) 13 tons if not
Falcon Heavy: 63800kg (if expended) ~ 30 to 40 if not

Space Shuttle: 27500 kg
